newsitem.title: USA: U.S. circulating new ideas to revive peace talks.
newsitem.headline: U.S. circulating new ideas to revive peace talks.

text.p: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu left Washington to return to Israel late on Monday after a tough two-hour meeting with President Bill Clinton failed to revive the Israeli-Palestinian peace talks.

The White House said Clinton offered new ideas to end an escalating spiral of violence over a new Israeli housing settlement project in Jerusalem, but no progress was reported after a session that a grim-faced president described as "very specific, frank, candid and long."
Netanyahu was tight-lipped about specifics, but told a packed American Israel Public Affairs Committee dinner before his departure that his talks in Washington were "excellent."
"I met with President Clinton and Secretary (of State Madeleine) Albright and we had very good meetings. We had open talks, excellent talks," the prime minister said.
"We have, I think, we have a sure friend in the White House -- actually two friends, the president and the vice president (Al Gore)," he said.

U.S., Israeli and Palestinian officials kept mum about specifics of new U.S. proposals aimed at keeping an outbreak of violence over new Jewish housing in East Jerusalem from derailing the Israeli-Palestinian peace process.

State Department spokesman Nicholas Burns said Netanyahu agreed during his meetings on Monday with Clinton, Albright and negotiator Dennis Ross to consider "specific American ideas", but he gave no details.

In remarks broadcast by Israel Radio, Netanyahu said Clinton "raised some suggestions for reviving the diplomatic process in a later stage ... I won't get into details, but I can say the talk of pressures and threats and things like that did not come up at all."

Netanyahu's foreign policy adviser Dore Gold told CNN's "Crossfire" the two reached a clear understanding that "for this process to go forward you can't have a link between bulldozers and dynamite ... between settlements and violence. Violence has to be removed from the process."

PLO official Hasan Rahman, on the same programme, rejected suggestions that Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat sanctioned the suicide bombing last month that killed three Israelis. "The first step is for Israel to stop building this illegal settlement and confiscating Palestinian land," he said.
Clinton said the next step was to discuss the U.S. proposals with the Palestinians, who are sending a negotiating team to Washington later this week.
"After the meetings with the Palestinians later this week, then we will consider our next steps as we attempt to put these negotiations back on track," Burns said.
The urgency of the talks was underscored by continued violence in the West Bank, where a Jewish settler shot and wounded at least two Palestinians on Monday.

Israeli-Palestinian peace talks have ceased and clashes have been reported every day since Israel broke ground for new Jewish housing last month on Har Homa, a 6,500-home settlement on an East Jerusalem hill known as Jabal Abu Ghneim in Arabic.

Gold called the land "a completely barren hill" and said nothing in the Israeli-Palestinian peace accords prohibited construction of new settlements, but Rahman said Israel was "unilaterally trying to determine the future of Jerusalem," which violated the spirit of the accords.
Administration officials say Albright may be sent to the region to follow up on Clinton's diplomatic efforts.

Netanyahu has proposed that he and Arafat reach a final peace agreement within six months, and said the goal may require an intensive three-way summit like the one that led to accords between Egypt and Israel.
